video.title: Code a 2D Game Using JavaScript, HTML, and CSS (w/ Free Game Assets) – Tutorial
video.description:
Let's explore an alien planet and learn all the techniques you need to make your own 2D games with vanilla JavaScript, HTML5, CSS3 and HTML Canvas. From sprite animation to parallax backgrounds, today we will build a game completely from scratch, with no frameworks and no libraries, using just HTML, CSS and plain vanilla JavaScript. Have fun!

✏️ Course by Frank's Laboratory. https://www.youtube.com/c/Frankslaboratory

🎨 Download Project Art assets 🎨
** All art assets for this class were made by Frank or by artists he hired, there is NO copyright, you can download and use these freely for any project you want!
Player: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/player.png
Projectile: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/projectile.png
Particle gears: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/gears.png
⚙️ Backgrounds:
Layer 1: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/layer1.png
Layer 2: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/layer2.png
Layer 3: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/layer3.png
Layer 4: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/layer4.png
🐟 Enemies:
Angler 1: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/angler1.png
Angler 2: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/angler2.png
Lucky Fish: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/lucky.png
Hive Whale: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/hivewhale.png
Drone: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/drone.png
☁️ Collision Animations: 
Smoke: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/smokeExplosion.png
Fire: https://www.frankslaboratory.co.uk/downloads/103/fireExplosion.png

🐟EXTENDED class with BONUS lessons and more free sprite sheets: 4 new enemies, sound design, animated shield, animated projectiles and more https://www.udemy.com/course/learn-game-development-with-javascript/?referralCode=69874A38D543D7F510F2

⭐️ Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro
⌨️ (0:01:07) HTML & CSS setup
⌨️ (0:02:40) Basic JavaScript setup
⌨️ (0:04:59) Object Oriented programming with JavaScript
⌨️ (0:07:25) Creating Player and Game objects
⌨️ (0:13:18) Animation loop
⌨️ (0:16:36) Keyboard inputs
⌨️ (0:26:15) Creating projectiles
⌨️ (0:33:22) Periodic events
⌨️ (0:38:30) Drawing game UI
⌨️ (0:41:20) Base enemy class
⌨️ (0:49:19) Collision detection between rectangles
⌨️ (0:54:36) Drawing game score
⌨️ (0:57:49) Win and lose condition
⌨️ (0:59:52) Counting game time
⌨️ (1:03:07) Animated parallax backgrounds
⌨️ (1:13:20) Sprite animation with JavaScript
⌨️ (1:17:02) Creating a debug mode
⌨️ (1:18:38) Animating enemy sprite sheets
⌨️ (1:25:15) Night Angler enemy class
⌨️ (1:27:39) Lucky Fish enemy class
⌨️ (1:29:02) Collecting power ups
⌨️ (1:36:51) Drawing projectiles as images
⌨️ (1:38:01) Custom fonts and game text
⌨️ (1:40:43) Cleaning up
⌨️ (1:42:51) Particle effects and physics
⌨️ (1:55:03) Particle rotation
⌨️ (1:58:47) Tweaks and fixes
⌨️ (2:01:46) Hive Whale enemy class
⌨️ (2:04:46) Drone enemy class
⌨️ (2:09:30) Dust effect animation
⌨️ (2:24:36) Fire effect animation
⌨️ (2:26:03) Tuning game difficulty
⌨️ (2:29:26) What to do next?

Thank you so much for taking the time to make this video series, and especially for making it freely available!

## Feedback
If you could separate writing the code and talking about the code, that would be really helpful, as it's hard to code along while also trying to understand what you're explaining.

## Question
Also, do you know why your extended course isn't showing up in Udemy Business? My employer has Udemy Business, so that's how I enroll in all my Udemy courses, but I couldn't find any of yours 😳

replies.author: Franks laboratory
replies.text: Hi Richard, thank you for your feedback. I'm still trying to improve how I do these courses. All my available classes should be a part of Udemy business, if it's not there it must have been removed by them recently, will check.

topLevelComment.author: Joseph Gassiraro
topLevelComment.text:
This is the first project I have ever done with JavaScript and @Franks laboratory, I just want to thank you for giving me the confidence to self-teach myself with your help. A question though, why do I have to put "this" in front of so many variables? I understand that using the word this makes it distinct somehow, but does the computer not know that by talking about a certain property in a class like height or size, I would be referring to the variable in the case of the class? I know it may be a simple question, but when I say this is my first coding project in JavaScript, it really is.

I did it!

replies.author: Darkaïne
replies.text:
The keyword "this" refers to the class we're in when used. For exemple in the class "Player" the attribute "this.height" allows us to use the attribute "height" of this class. In OOP(Oriented Object Programming) "this" refers to the local class.
If you are outside any call and want to use an attribute you'll use for exemple "game.score" but if you are inside the Game class you'll use "this.score".

topLevelComment.author: S
topLevelComment.text: I have a 144hz refresh rate and thus the game runs faster. what code i should use to make it normal?

replies.author: Franks laboratory
replies.text: Use delta time in the main animation loop, create timer and interval variables, interval sets fps, for example 1000/60 to get ms amount for 60fps. accumulate deltaTime in timer, when it reaches interval, only then animate the game and then reset timer back to 0 for the next frame. I will show exactly how to do this in my upcoming gamedev class. Working on it now.

topLevelComment.text: I had saved the images from your link to my desktop, how can i make it show in my browser? Its not working any help!

replies.author: Franks laboratory
replies.text: @YANUR ALI  you can check if the images are being drawn before you set display to none with CSS. Console log your image variables. Double check draw Image syntax. Its hard to help you without seeing your code but there is a typo there somewhere

replies.author: YANUR ALI
replies.text: @Franks laboratory i have created a folder named “Projects” in my desktop where i have another folder name “assets” that includes the images i’ve downloaded and rest are the index.html,style.css and script.js. Yet its not working !!

replies.author: Franks laboratory
replies.text: Put the images in your project folder and follow steps I outline in the tutorial.

topLevelComment.author: Mahmoud Atia Ead
topLevelComment.text:
at 1:18:32
i can not use this.game.debug inside eventLestener , because "this" here is the window not the InputHandler

replies.author: Mahmoud Atia Ead
replies.text: Thanks a lot, you are a good teacher by the way :)

replies.author: Franks laboratory
replies.text: I show how to solve that in this video, did you watch the whole thing? Use es6 arrow function instead of a regular function in the callback of event listener. Arrow functions inherit 'this' from the parent scope so it will refer to InputHandler object correctly.

Just one suggestion: because of its length and the fact that all the code is in one file, sometimes it was difficult to debug. Having the finished files would be of great help. It would be great if you could create a GitHub repo or post them somewhere.

Thank you so much!

replies.author: YungTyyler
replies.text:
@Franks laboratory hello,
Yes my apologies, I meant 6.9 not 16.9… my bad. I will look at things again and keep messing around with it. Thank you!

replies.author: Franks laboratory
replies.text: @YungTyyler 144hz screen will have much lower deltaTime than 16.9, all your animations you run that use requestAnimationFrame method will run 2.5 times faster unless you throttle it using the deltaTime technique

replies.author: YungTyyler
replies.text: @Franks laboratory I’ve got 144hz so I’m getting about 16.9 I believe

replies.author: Franks laboratory
replies.text: Hi, I assume you have high refresh rate gaming screen? If you console log deltaTime from inside animation loop are you getting 16.6 or a lower value?

replies.text:
For some reason I also got stuck there for a second, I missed the bang operator ! for marking the particles for deletion
Checking this section bellow and make sure you have the !particle.markedForDeletion inside of the Game 
this.particles = this.particles.filter(
        (particle) =>

replies.author: Franks laboratory
replies.text: Hi Andrea, well done on getting so far, you need to console log the array that holds the objects and inspect those objects, in most cases some property like their x coordinate is undefined and JavaScript doesn't know where to draw them. When you know what's undefined you can track where that value is calculated and fix the issue. Also put a console log inside draw and update method of the problematic object to make sure those methods are actually running.

topLevelComment.author: Giorgos Kyrenes
topLevelComment.text:
I don't know if you change the code later, but I'll comment on this anyway in case I forget it later.
So, you don't need to use an array for the game.keys and check each time what is included. You can just use a Set, which can only have unique values.
I think this significantly simplifies the code.

replies.author: poornesh hn
replies.text: Also it reduces look up times like indexof and includes significantly.

replies.author: Franks laboratory
replies.text: Hi Giorgos, this is an excellent idea, thank you for sharing

replies.author: Franks laboratory
replies.text: Classes and prototypes are the same thing with a different syntax. I'm not sure where exactly you would suggest the changes, probably things with a single instance like Game class could have been a single object rather than a class. It's just to tidy up, it would not change anything about how the code works
